Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: One day last fall, Bryant Woods’ rotted-out flooring opened up beneath his 11-year-old daughter. Major leaks in the rental home had allowed mold to thrive and rot to set in. In the winters, he was forced to use space heaters or his electric oven to stay warm since the heat didn’t work.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bryant Woods is a tenant who experienced severe housing issues, including mold and rot, and was forced to use space heaters or his electric oven to stay warm due to a lack of heat.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: For years, Woods’ relationship with his longtime landlord has been deteriorating. About nine months ago, the two men agreed he could withhold rent until repairs were made, he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bryant Woods is a tenant who had a deteriorating relationship with his landlord and agreed to withhold rent until repairs were made.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Then, recently, his landlord caught him by surprise and filed for eviction. He couldn’t prove his missed rent payments were part of a verbal agreement, so the judge granted the property owner’s request and told Woods his family had 10 days to move.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bryant Woods was evicted after his landlord filed for eviction, and he couldn’t prove his missed rent payments were part of a verbal agreement.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: To reduce such evictions, one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge who, along with Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon and Cindy Ettingoff, secured funding for a pre-litigation mediation program to reduce evictions.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The initial goal was for MALS to use the money to hire a few employees — including a former code inspector since property conditions almost always drive the disputes.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge involved in the pilot program aimed at reducing evictions by addressing property conditions.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: But receiving the money from the county turned into an adventure. The cash didn’t make it to MALS until February 2024, due to problems with how the County Commission resolution was originally drafted, Henderson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge who explained the delays in receiving funding for the mediation program due to issues with the County Commission resolution.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Recently, MALS worked with a woman who was living in a house that “should not be lived in by anyone” and was starting to fall behind on rent, Henderson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge who described a case where MALS helped a tenant living in uninhabitable conditions.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Though the program has only helped a couple of tenants so far — not 300 — Henderson believes it’s already proving its value.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge who believes the mediation program is proving its value despite helping only a few tenants so far.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are no income limits or income requirements,” Henderson told a WLOK-AM audience earlier this summer. “If you’re a tenant who is having trouble with your landlord, you need to give us a call. ... If you’re a landlord and you have a troublesome tenant ... give us a call.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge who promoted the mediation program on a radio show, emphasizing that there are no income limits or requirements.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Nicole Grida, the new MALS CEO, said her team has started creating marketing materials for the program, building partnerships with local nonprofits and screening folks who call in for other services to see if they will fit the program’s criteria, which has resulted in many promising leads.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Nicole Grida is the new CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services who is leading efforts to promote the mediation program and build partnerships.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: For the program to succeed, Grida said raising greater awareness will be key, as most Memphians it could help don’t yet know it exists.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Nicole Grida is the CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services who emphasized the importance of raising awareness for the mediation program.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Woods’ case, for instance, sounded like a perfect fit for mediation, Henderson said, if only they’d found him before the eviction was filed.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge who believes Bryant Woods’ case would have been a good fit for mediation if they had found him before the eviction was filed.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We could have drafted a document that ensured the landlord (followed the verbal agreement),” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge who explained how the mediation program could have helped Bryant Woods by drafting a document to ensure the landlord followed the verbal agreement.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Henderson believes the program will require a much longer pilot period before it’s able to produce the proof necessary to create a housing court. But, despite the rough start, she remains “very hopeful” for its future.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Deborah Henderson is a judge who believes the mediation program will need a longer pilot period to prove its value but remains hopeful for its future.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: To reduce such evictions, one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Memphis Area Legal Services, along with Judge Deborah Henderson and Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon, secured funding for a pre-litigation mediation program to reduce evictions.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The initial goal was for MALS to use the money to hire a few employees — including a former code inspector since property conditions almost always drive the disputes.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Memphis Area Legal Services planned to use the funding to hire employees, including a former code inspector, to address property conditions that drive disputes.
